title: Happy Halloween - the musical cow
excerpt:
For the first time since we've lived in Seattle, we've had lots of kids for Halloween We had so many kids we ran out of candy, which is a good thing since if the kids don't eat the candy, we will.

Another first occurred today - Zach put on his Halloween costume. Check out the awesome musical cow videos here.

title: Week 131AZ: The leaves they are a changing
excerpt: Today is a sunny Sunday and we can see the glorious leaves changing colors as they fall (pun intended). We had to skip circus school this week as we had a double party schedule- first the kids from our birth group and second our neighbors birthday party.

title: Best friend is a hard post to hold
excerpt: Monday night Zach and I went to REI to play on their tree. There were a bunch of 7 year olds there, and Zach was playing tag and hide an seek with them. While Zach played I heard a little girl, Sally, describe Zach to her Dad:

title: Week 130AZ: Mommy is my best friend
excerpt: When I asked Zach who his best friend is he said "Mommy". Speaking of cute, Zach and I are on the couch as I write this, he's licking his popsicle leaning on my chest in the crook of my right arm which is wrapped around him and I'm typing. It's a pretty charming photo of the modern family. Luckily Zach has heard about napkins, and he's now asking his mom for one while his popsicle drips on me.

title: Week 129AZ: Stealing the coffee cup
excerpt: I tend to steal Tori's coffee cup, it's a problem I have. You'd reason it's a problem Tori has - since taking the coffee cup doesn't bother me. But reason harder- if Tori has a problem I have a problem, so it's my problem after all.

title: Week 128AZ: Sun and Bikes
excerpt: Zach took his bike to the corner store, picked up an apple, a bottle of wine and headed home. On the way he stopped to eat his apple and I took this photo. I have to say, between the bike, the apple, and the wine - that's my kid no doubt about it.

title: First Bike Ride w/Zach
excerpt: It was pitch black, but fun anyways! Zack has now learned the power of pedaling.

title: Week 127AZ: Rest and Relaxation
excerpt: This week was all about decompressing, I've been on vacation and taking it easy. Baba left for home on Wednesday, and Tori and I have been chilling for the last four days. As usual, we try to keep Zach entertained, so we hit the harvest festival, went to the zoo, saw Mel, tackled circus school, and spent lots of time playing in the backyard.

title: Why yes, that is a park in my backyard
excerpt:
It's always nice to be wrong, especially when I'm wrong, Tori's right, and Zach's happy as a two year old at a park.

For a while, Tori has wanted to fill our back yard with a giant play set. Even though she asked me if I was interested, and I said I was, I secretly expected this would be an albatross - filling our backyard, and completely ignored.

title: Week 126AZ: BABA!
excerpt: This week Baba came to visit and it's awesome to watch her interact with Zach! Zach loves telling Baba stories, and Baba loves hearing them. Zach also loves to boss Baba around, and Baba doesn't seem to mind at all.

title: Week 125AZ: Potty Training Begins
excerpt: We've decided it's time to teach Zach to use a potty. We ordered special "get wet" panties, that let Zach know when he's wet himself, and we've got a bag of cheerios on the bathroom sink. So far, Zach just pee's through his "get wet" panties and eats the cheerios, but we suspect progress is imminent.

title: Have a good trip Ash!
excerpt: Here is a short photo blog of Ash, you'll be missed buddy.

title: Week 124AZ: Memorizing all the books
excerpt: Every night before bed, I read Zach bed time stories, it's an interactive experience where I ask Zach questions and he gets them right. Lately I started pausing and letting him fill in words like an intense No - he had no troubles. Then, I wondered just how well he knew the stories, and I let him fill in a random word per sentence. Turns out, he can do that too. Looks like Zach is basically memorizing all of his bed time stories - pretty frickin cool.

title: Week 123AZ:Squawk
excerpt: This was a long week (heck, long month), and I've been really busy at work. As such, I haven't been getting my Tori and Zach hours in. Thankfully, this weekend, we've been spending lots of time together, which really makes my day.

title: Week 122AZ: The Maureen and Brian come to Town
excerpt: Maureen and Brian of Ranch fame came to town with their dogs Lilly and Cochise. They're camping out in our backyard and it's almost as much fun to have them here as it is to go to their place. Since they were here we used the third row seats in the RAV4 and were able to ram 4 adults, 2 dogs and 1 Zach into our car for our many journeys! I can't articulate why stuffing many people into a car makes me happy, maybe it's my circus tendencies, but it does!

title: Week 121AZ: Awesome Circus School and Street Canoing
excerpt: Zach has been going to circus school for 8 weeks now, and this week was the first time he did the entire class without calling out he wanted to go home or be picked up! This is huge progress, usually Zach wants to leave right away, or cries to be picked up as soon as we start doing any exercises! Great Job Zach we're totally proud of you.

title: My favorite time of year and the funniest thing Zach said to me
excerpt: I was telling Tori how much I enjoy my 30's as I'm starting to understand what I like - for example early august is my favorite time of year. It's hot out, and the days are long enough but not too long. While I was rather proud of my new found discovery, Tori assures me I've been saying this every year around this time:) Any who - Zach and I were out Kayaking yesterday and we had the following conversation:

title: Week 120AZ: Camel Rides
excerpt: _This weekend we went to renaissance fair, and Zach got to ride a camel - not only did Zach enjoy riding the camel, but he enjoyed feeding the camel too - who would have guessed! In case you're wondering, we didn't come in costume, but we'll plan better for next year.

title: Week 119AZ: Zach and Jonah
excerpt: We finished the week with an amazing joy, we got to watch our good friend . This was our first 5 hours with 2 2 year old experience, and it was a riot. Zach and Jonah were playing together, having a blast, and hopefully learning from each other. We'll do this again.

title: Week 118AZ: Hello From Guemes!
excerpt: This long weekend (Saturday - Tuesday) we took a vacation at Guemes Island Resort. Guemes is a crabbing resort, but we didn't have the desire to catch crabs so we went kayaking, beach walking and saunaing instead.

title: Week 117AZ: Hello from the rainbow staircase
excerpt: Tori has completed her rainbow stair case vision, and Zach and I love it. The only thing cooler than that art installation that inspires you, is having that art installation be your home. The stairs are even cooler then they look in the photo as the upstairs landing has another 4 colored walls, and a hanging chair. To top off the exhibit, when the sun sets several of the walls in the landing actually glow in the sunset. AWESOME JOB TORI!

title: Week 116AZ:  Tori shows how it's done
excerpt: This week saw the french doors properly hung and the storage unit emptied. On top of that, Zach's got a bed in his room, and even spent the night in it on Friday! Take a bow my dear partner Tori you deserve it!

title: Summer Nights 1: Ben/Sam/Ice Cream/Head Gash
excerpt: You get a new enjoyment of summer when you have kids. Zach and I hung out with Paul and his kids (the famous Ben and Sam) and we all had a riot. Sure it was fun and games till Zach bashed his head in a water fountain, but I was nearby, and ice cream fixed it.

title: Zach's First Kayak Ride
excerpt: Today Zach went on his first Kayak ride. It was short, and went quite well. Initially, Zach was pretty scared so he was still as a mouse, but then he got his courage and decided he should be in charge of paddling. This was a bit of a problem, but luckily I still weigh 6 times as much as Zach and can over power him in a pinch.

title: Week 115AZ: Summer is here
excerpt: Summer has arrived in Seattle. For the 4th of July we got a chance to see some backyard fireworks, where Zach spent the entire event in my lap (Tori's rules) screaming "Mo, FiWook". Zach is turning into a commentator - he loves sitting on the sideline calling the shots (it''s possibly he's giving orders, we'll know in a few weeks no doubt)

title: Week 114AZ: Choocka Chooka Choo Choo
excerpt: Tori and I are blessed to watch Zach grow developmentally. This week we were thrilled to watch  Zach driving trains while saying Chaka Chaka Choo Choo and to watch Zach stopping and sit everywhere (like the sidewalk in the middle of downtown) and turn an imaginary steering wheel while yelling "Vroom" "Vroom".

title: Jump Jump Jump
excerpt:
Jump Jump Jump, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Sometimes Dad's can still teach the kids how to play!

title: Week 113AZ: Birthday Season Pride
excerpt: Every week seems to be a birthday party and I love it. I'm using a picture from last week's birthday party in which Zach is taking Tori for a drive in a car that hasn't moved for a while (Seattle Play Garden for the locals ).

title: Week 112AZ: Zach's first Solstice Parade
excerpt: I'm a huge fan of the fremont solstice parade (life goal: put a float into the parade). This week Zach and I partook, and after sitting on the sidelines as spectators - I decided we should participate by being run over by the giant beach ball ( a 10 ft diameter beach ball which is continuously flattening the crowds). Sadly when I lied down in the street with the beach ball approaching Zach was not pleased and would have none of it. Once I'd tasted participation, I couldn't help myself and Zach and I walked in the parade! It was awesome, I have circus monkey in the blood, and I need to encourage the same gene in Zach.

title: Week 111AZ: Kiss it better
excerpt:
This week we'll start with **three funnies** :

**One)** While we were downtown Zach was swinging a stick like a Kung Fu master, I said

"Zach! Stop before you hurt someone"

Zach replied

"It's OK - I'll kiss it better".

title: Week 110AZ: Life's a beach
excerpt:
In theater there is a saying: Every Play Opens and Every Play Closes.

Tori's play opened, and Igor got through a 4 day x 12 hour work week too. Now we're back to our regularly scheduled programming and very much looking forward to it.

title: Week 109AZ: Did he really read that?
excerpt: This weekend Tori's play is in Tech (aka: Crazy Busy High Stress Time) so she is slammed. The whole family (Tori included) look forward to Tori getting sleep and time to her self now that the play is wrapped up.

title: Week 108AZ: Birthday; Nap; Party; Sleep; Park; Birthday; Nap; Play; Sleep

I dunno how Tori gets through the week, just the weekend can over exert me. This weekend we had a busier than most weekend which I'll use as my excuse for a crappy blog post

**Saturday:**

Birthday

Nap

Party

excerpt:
Zach and the harmonica a video by idvorkin on Flickr.

title: Week 107AZ: Teaching
excerpt: Zach goes to a co-op preschool where parents attend along with their kids. All the parents got to provide a one sentence description about all the other kids. Here is the description of Zach the preschool teacher assembled from the other parent's description:

title: Week 106AZ: No Daddy No
excerpt: "No Daddy No" is starting to feel like Zach's favorite word. For example, Zach loves diggers, and when we went to the park, he was playing with the one in the picture. Zach isn't big enough to sit in the seat and operate the digger arms, so I tried to help him. Instead of taking my help, Zach screamed "No Daddy No", pushed me off, and stopped playing with it.

title: Week 105AZ: Daddy Tea; Mommy Coffee; Zachy Coco
excerpt: Daddy Tea, Mommy Coffee, Zachy Coco - said Zach as our family enjoyed our morning beverages. On another morning Zach ran to Mom, got a hard boiled egg, then ran to the couch, and yelled at me to turn on Pocoyo (a kids TV show). Next, Zach sat on the floor, leaning back against the couch. Then, while watching TV, Zach cracked open his hard boiled egg on the floor, and had breakfast watching TV.

title: Thanks for all the Cake
excerpt:
IMG_3172, a photo by idvorkin on Flickr.

Uncle Ammon and Aunt Elise made Zach a big yellow school bus chocolate cake. For which Mr. Dvorkin and Master Dvorkin are most grateful. Thanks for the all the cake!

title: Week 104AZ:  Wickles
excerpt:
What did I discover Zach interacting with this week?

1. Wickles \- Wickles are the greatest hot sweet pickle known to man. Zach loves them, and even though his face wrinkles a bit when he eats (they are spicy) he still demands more.

title: Sunday's Hobo Blogging - Capital Hill (10th and Pike)
excerpt: Sunday mornings we have a baby sitter so Tori and I normally walk over to the local coffee shop where Tori does school work, and I do work work, or blog work. The last few Sunday's Tori has been on site for her play, and I've been dropping her off since it makes me feel manly. While I wait for Tori to finish work, I rent some space and an internet connection from a local coffee shop.

title: Week 103AZ: Daddy Work Go Bye Bye
excerpt:
Tori and Zach picked me up from work on Tuesday, and as we pulled out of the parking lot Zach exclaimed:

It blew my mind, just a few short weeks ago Zach could barely say Dada and Mamma, and now he's coming up with abstract concepts.

title: Week 102AZ: One Bus; Two Buses
excerpt:
Yesterday Zach actually said one bus, two buses. Where does he come up with this grammar stuff?

Last week was tough, Zach had a fever, and was sick, and I've had a fever and then a soar throat, and I'm finally feeling better. Me and Zach being sick is brutal hard on Tori, since she takes up the slack. Zach and I are grateful - let me say that again, Zach and I are grateful for all you do for us.

title: Week 101: Little Boy
excerpt:
I needed to come up with something clever to say and I failed.

Monday (Today) Zach was a little bear, he has a fever so he's mean as molasses (is that a real simile?) . When Zach's in a bad mood it's contagious and Mommy and Daddy claw at each other.

title: Week 100AZ: Seattle Sun Shining
excerpt:
Spring, which I define as sun and warm days, came to Seattle this weekend. The timing is perfect as Tori has completed her exams and Zach has picked up a plethora of new tricks:

Zach now says happy and sad. When he gets an owie he's sad. When we play with other kids he's happy.

title: Week 99AZ: It's a marathon not a sprint

title: The evolution of HOT
excerpt:
A cool thing about having kids is you get to see how they evolve and develop. For non-computer weenies you get to watch them grow up :)

In the beginning when Zach couldn't talk we used the word HOT to indicate that food was too hot for Zach and he'd have to wait before he could have some. Zach understood this, so then we started using the word HOT to mean something wasn't safe. For example we say the furnace is HOT (actually - it's cool to the touch). Zach even started to use HOT for dangerous, when Zach was afraid of the shower he'd scream HOT if ever I tried to take him near a shower, even if I showed him the water was luke warm.

title: Week 85AZ: Cold Be Gone!
excerpt: After four months of the most frigid seattle winter we've had in years without a furnace, we have cast a spell of natural gas, large sums of money and competent workers and presto WE HAVE HEAT. In general Zach is indifferent to our largest appliance, with the exception that he's bummed he can no longer drop cat food down the holes that were our vents. While the delays we had were avoidable, there is some silver lining to this experience - which my dear son I want you to burn into the back of your head when you read this :). First always listen to your wife, she's right. Second, don't take for granted the things you have. Simple things life a roof over your head and heat coming out your vents bring you great pleasure. When you think things are truly crappy, you have lost perspective. Backup and see all the wonderful things you do have, a loving family, friends, your health, maybe even some heat if you're lucky.

title: Week 72AZ: Better at Everything
excerpt:
Sorry Zachster, it's been a long while since the last update - I'll try to do better. On the bright side, we've made lots of pictures and movies.

What really amazes me about Zach is how he's getting better at everything. A trivial example is how Zach walks down the stairs. A few weeks ago Zach would simply step down, and he wouldn't care where his weight bearing leg was (resulting in falls). Now Zach knows better, and makes sure his weight bearing leg is as close possible to edge before stepping down. It's cool to watch the development. Zach's learning to play with balls and it's super fun to watch. He'll pick up a ball, go to throw it forward, and then be confused when it flies backwards. I'm sure a few more weeks and he'll be throwing the ball farther than I can fetch it.

title: Back In My Pants: About Juice Fasting
excerpt:
Juice Fasting is eating (technically drinking) nothing but fruit and vegetable juice, water and tea.

The internet is full of juice fasting stories, most of them written by laymen, or as I like to say "Quacks and Hippies". The quacks and hippies make it hard for someone to determine what components of juicing are beneficial. For example, is not digesting food the key? Or is it the fact you're getting severe calorie reduction?

To give some context, I've been extremely unhealthy of late, my weight has reached an out of control 230lbs, and I've been ignoring diet and exercise. The next day I watched the movie, and started on a health kick like no other I've been on.

title: Our First Zach Freak Out
excerpt: Less than 24 hours after Zach was born, Zach's breathing was crazy fast - more than 60 breaths per second (medical jargon: Respiratory Distress). We just had a home birth, and had no desire to go to the hospital, where we expected hospital staff would run oodles of tests on Zach and not let us have him back. As we were trying to decide if we needed to go to the hospital, I was counting Zach's breathing every few minutes. I recall thinking that keeping track of Zach's fast breathing was causing me my own respistory distress.

title: The two minute Sencha problem.
excerpt:
IMG_1122

Originally uploaded by idvorkin

(Gratuitous picture of Zach for those not interested in my forgetfulness)

Sencha is a green tea that is wonderful when prepared correctly but awful if not brewed properly. To make a good cup of sencha you must have water at the right temperature and you must steep for 2 minutes. Steep Sencha too long and it is bitter and nasty. Temperature is easy for me, but not over brewing is a huge pain. Two minutes is too long for me to do nothing, so I start doing the 'next thing' and forget about my tea. As I ponder my ruined tea dilemma it occurs to me the answer to my problem might be a 2 minute breathing exercise between prepare and drink. As I ponder more, it seems I'll have the same problem - perhaps I'll go out and buy an egg timer instead

title: Don’t Wait to do a bad job – Combating Procrastination
excerpt:
My most expensive type of procrastination is I have to do something I don’t want to do – for example writing my review at work.

Because I don’t want to write my review, I don’t.

But, since I’m not writing my review, I feel guilty and can’t do other work things that would be very valuable but aren’t as urgent as writing my review.

title: Kind gestures, and the responses they produce are overwhelming.
excerpt:
I watched an interesting documentary about a death row chaplin called At Death's door. My favorite memory from the movie:

A convict that was going to die in a few hours kept telling the chaplin how he loved cigars. So the chaplin went to the 7/11 and brought the convict a cigar, and put the cigar in the convicts pocket just before they put the convict in the gurney to be killed. The chaplin described: The convict kept looking at his pocket and smiling. I'll never forget the smile on the convicts face, and the happiness that moment brought both of us.

title: I'm Engaged!
excerpt:

this one .

For the curious, Tori's bride price is:

Two cows to bring milk and income to a Russian village. Two sheep to help families in Arizona produce wool. Two camels to help families in Tanzania earn income by transporting agricultural and industrial materials. Two oxen to pull plows and carts in Uganda. Two water buffalo to help Cambodian families increase rice production through animal draft power. And 10 other pairs of animals not even mentioned.

title: Hiccup - Connecting with your inner tadpole.
excerpt:
I just read Your Inner Fish and loved it. It's a story of our evolution, and presents some interesting ideas in a easy to read, entertaining fashion.

My favorite part of the book is the explanation of hiccups. Hiccups the author explains , are how tadpoles use their gills without flooding their lungs. If you're feeling nerdy check out:A phylogenetic hypothesis for the origin of hiccough.

title: It's not about being able to answer questions. It's about knowing the questions to ask.

title: World Cafeteria Tour Berlin
excerpt: Planned as world museum tour Berlin, we had a full schedule. To ensure a good start, we started with some hearty sausage and cabbage, and followed up with some rum balls. With our bellies full, we headed to the museum. My poor planning failed to notice that the museum was closed on Mondays, so we were sad. Mulled wine with rum (something we'll have to investigate for our next party) took the edge off as we searched for the next museum. We got distracted by a search for Frank Gehry's whale and then a epic journey to find the remains of the Berlin wall drained our resources. We needed to re-charge and a meat sandwich hit the spot. Next we quested for the German parliament and lego land. A few shots with me and a giraffe later, and it was time for coffee and apple strudel. I'm told for apple strudel in Berlin there is only one choice - Einsteins, and I have to agree.

This symbolizes that the books can be destroyed but the ideas can not.

title: The Pope's revenge.
excerpt: Like the CN tower in Toronto, and the Space needle in Seattle, Berlin has a big phallic symbol for its city. It's called the TV tower - think CN Tower with a disco ball. Built by the communists after the war to prove communist superiority it comes with a few funny stories. First it was the second largest building in Europe when it was built. Who would build a second largest tower you ask? Well, it turns out the tallest tower was the Moscow TV tower,and communist pride wouldn't allow you to build a tower bigger than the one in the mother land. To understand the second funny thing about the tower you need to understand that Russia doesn't believe in religion, so it is constantly tearing down religious artifacts like crosses. Well it turns out when the sun reflects on the disco ball in the TV tower, it forms a giant cross made of reflecting sunlight - this is what Berliners call the Pope's revenge :)

title: And what do you think?
excerpt:
Tori's kin got a chance to see our Flickr photos, and they provided a funny review. We haven't had a chance to meet them yet but hopefully this fall. Their witty response below:

> OK Victoria, Brian and I went to the picture site and looked at quite a few photos. We were especially impressed by the window display of the carved wooden dicks. Christmas shopping? If so, I'll pass, but I think they'd be perfect for the rest of the family. Especially Kathy. I know she doesn't already have one. I have a lovely tin you can pack it in. We also liked the shot of Igor au naturale with his keyboard in his lap. Very few can get away with a shot like that. And since none of the rest of us have men without raging inhibitions it makes for a nice change. Want me to print it out and show it to your Grandmother? Maybe it will start a trend. Perhaps Ed will consider posing with a circular saw or Scott will vogue with a stick of dynamite. Very carefully placed. As for the house...it would have been more interesting to see the house rather than your collection of college-era furniture. You might want to consider going to the dump...Nonetheless, the house looks way better than many of the places we lived, and the neighborhood does indeed appear to be respectable. Hopefully the three of you won't spoil that. Life on the Ranch hasn't changed much. The new calf is well and I just bought a highland heifer from Yakima, WA who should be arriving next month I think. Her name is Lass, and she is bred, so her calf is expected next March. She's pedigreed up the wazoo, so the ranch is going upscale. Either that or I'm just pissing away money. Depends on whether you're talking to me or Brian.

Finally, I'm not sure why no one could figure out what Ryan was for Halloween, but everyone agreed he was scary.

title: My first bike tour - not quite Olympia
excerpt: Today I went on my first bike tour. It was a two day credit card supported tour. Woohoo! Here is a picture of me passing some other cyclist on the green river trail. The other picture is the seedy hotel I stayed at.

title: Socio-Economics and biking
excerpt:
Being rich means having stuff, with having stuff comes a desire not to lose stuff, and it's this desire that makes me feel safe biking through rich neighborhoods.

Today I biked through some poor neighborhoods, it reminded me of the slums I biked through in Phoenix. The ones where they had no plumbing. Imagine a modern city without plumbing.

title: Climbin' and Cavin' at Tiger Mountain
excerpt: Turns out there is alot more to tiger mountain than the main ascent. I took a turn for the 'nook' at Tiger and found some easy climbs, and a cool cave! Very Funky. Make sure you bring your headlamp as it's pitch black.

title: Blake Island Boat Camping
excerpt: For weeks my buddy (see legs portruding from truck), has been trying to get a group together to go boat camping. This weekend he succeeded, and it was a blast. Three of us boated over to Blake island. We brought lots of stuff, none of which was firewood or matches, but hey - who needs fire.

title: Midnight Madness
excerpt: Tonight at midnight, I raced around greenlake. This was a bizarre event. It started with a 7 bike wipe out which I narrowly avoided. With the pile up behind me I greeted twists and turns in the near pitch black. To ice the cake, the sprinklers would go on making the road slick and visibility drop from a few feet to zero.

title: One hip cat
excerpt: It's like a different kind of biathlon.

title: Love Birds
excerpt: Aren't there more fun things you can do with your mate?

title: Bandera Mountain - 3.5 Mile Hike + 0.5 Liters of Water = Very Dehydrated.
excerpt: Saturday I went for a hike with some friends up Bandera mountain. It started as a fun hike, but very quickly I realized I didn't have enough water. Once I got used to being thirsty, I was thrilled to discover that that last 3/4 miles of Bandera is a hands and knees hike, going up at a 40 - 50 degree slope. A pretty cool view from the top though.

title: Take a second to smell the flowers!
excerpt: Today I went to the Skaget Valley Tulip festival. I can't get over how many flowers there were. There were literally acres of beautiful tulips. This festival was a delight!

title: Man + birds == great movie
excerpt:
Last night some friends of mine were going to a movie that sounded interesting and I decided to join them.

The movie was called "The wild parrots of telegraph hill" and was wonderful. That isn't the neatest part of this story. After the movie, the movie's star, Mark Bittner, was at the theater answering questions.

title: Consumption vs Production
excerpt: I'm not talking about production in the sense of Marx or Wealth of Nations, instead I'm talking about making stuff, baking a pie, or rebuilding an engine. In the same vein consumption means using things other people produced. Eating an apple or watching a movie for example.

title: Have you been  ComposicaGoogalized?
excerpt: Today I went in search of an old friend of mine named Micheal Lacroix. To do this I typed his name into google. It turns out the first hit in google was a musical composer. Normally I wouldn't care about this, but when you search for my name in google you find a composer that has my name.

title: Mint, radishes, and little men named Larry
excerpt:
Today I've planted my first garden. Mint, radishes, flowers, and some jalapeneo peppers.

Of course, the whole plot will be gaurded by my gnome Larry.

title: What do you do with a lot of carrots?
excerpt:
Make a cake of course!

Kudos to my roommate for making this fine carrot delight.

title: Do you believe in mind monsters?
excerpt:
Last night I was having trouble sleeping so I plopped down on the couch to watch infomercials. The infomercial I picked was religious in nature, and was talking about mind monsters.

At first I was laughing out load, laughing at how gullible people must be to believe in this stuff. Mind Monsters - what a silly idea - sheesh. Then I started listening. The mind monsters this evangelist was describing were the negative emotions we all have. Negative emotions like anger, and ego. This evangelist was preaching the same ideas any good book on Buddhism and Taoism often discusses.

title: A frog, a bear and an orangutang are sitting in a bar...
excerpt:
Unfortunately I don't know a cheeky joke about the above mentioned criters , but I do have a sweet picture.

From left to right that's Louie, Joey and Bertha

title: It's not easy finding interesting things to blog about
excerpt: Sometimes you have to cheat and put up an odd picture. Here is my odd picture. What do you think it is? I'll give you a hint you can find it in my home.

title: Flat Stanley at the bottom of the ocean.
excerpt: Flat Stanley is a boy that was crushed by a chalk boad, and ended up flat. Because Stanley is flat he can go all over the world. Today Flat Stanley can be found at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean. Where will we find Flat Stanley next?

title: Who wants to hear me talking to myself?
excerpt: Isn't that all this is, me talking to myself? Really that's all a blog is. I expect my mom and dad want to here the little voices in my head, but I can't think of that many other people this would interest.

title: Reduce and Reuse - Don't Recycle!
excerpt: I go a little batty when folks praise the merits of recycling. Far too often, recycling is used as a justification for our unbounded wastefulness. Compared to reducing and reusing recycling is a terrible choice. There is so much we can do with our "disposable" items. Here's a great example of someone reusing paper grocery bags for gift wrapping. Not only are they reusing, but even better, they're reducing the amount of trash they'd have produced by buying wrapping paper.

title: Happy Holidays
excerpt: Merry Days everyone. May you all be as well fed as we are!

title: Caught on the bridge.
excerpt: Last night I was walking home across a draw bridge. As I was about a 1/4 across I saw the gauds coming down, and then I heard the bridge moving. Getting a bit concerned I started running across the bridge. Luckily the bridge operator saw me, and stopped opening the bridge. I jumped the middle and crossed safely. After I got off the bridge, I watched as the bridge opened and the two halves of the bridge went vertical. Kind of scary.

title: Working from home
excerpt: One of the many anonymous souls on the internet.

title: A Helping Hand
excerpt:
Last night as I was walking back to my car at the grocery store I was approached by a panicked older woman.

"Help Me " she said.

"How can I be of assistance ma'am" , I replied, thinking something terrible had happened.

title: The Machine Ate My Card
excerpt: Today I needed some money so I went to the bank machine. I inserted by debit card, typed in that I wanted 80 $ and waited. Suddenly, the machine printed: " Error, card expired - card will not be returned".

title: Wink Wink Nudge Nudge, Another Police Story.
excerpt:
It seems everytime I go out with my white male friend, we always seem to get noticed by the police.

This time, my friend and I were getting ready for a dive in a not quite legal location. To keep the story readable we'll call this location mukilteo. I've given at mukilteo on several occasions, and I've never been bothred by the police.

title: Police Warnings and Racial Profiling
excerpt:
Today I had a funny.

My white male friend and I got stopped by the police . The police man said we were only getting a warning, but he would have to write it up because of racial profiling.

I asked the policeman about this racial profiling. The policeman explained that he had to write up all warnings to prove that he didn't racial profile. He explained that the demographic that gets the most tickets depends on your geographic location. He continued that in north seattle, he mostly pulls over white females, as they are the majority of drivers.

title: 565AZ - YUMMY SNOWSTORMS

title: 567AZ - COMING OUT OF HIBERNATION
excerpt: The other day, I was walking in the backyard, and saw our first daffodil. It’s been a long year due to the corona virus, but the end is now in sight. Vaccines are here and being distributed, people are wearing masks, the days are getting longer and the flowers are poking through.

title: 577AZ END OF CORONA VIRUS - THE PARK!
excerpt: After 14 months of isolation, as 70% of Seattlites have had their first jab, the CDC declared fully vaccinated people can stop wearing masks! I jumped at the opportunity to meet Johnny, someone I’ve worked with very closely, but never met in person. We chose meeting at the park, and given my new found freedom, I dusted off my haven’t used them in 16 months juggling clubs, my barely touched in 5 month magic fanny pack, and pedaled off!

title: 578AZ - PERFECT CAMPING TRIP
excerpt: Family, Fire, Friends, Beach, Yurt - what could be better? Not much, this week we went to twin harbor state park (near Ocean shores) and met Miga and some of her friends. It was a perfect trip, the kids had a blast, we got a blast of good weather in the middle, and I got to meet new folks and practice my magic and juggling.

title: ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED - BUBBLE BIKE
excerpt: I start my eulogy with my role as a dealer of smiles and wonder and bicycle rider. For a reason I don’t understand, few things are so universally smile generating as bubbles. Normally, bubbles are limited to your lung capacity, but a few years back I discovered bubble machines, which automatically create a metric tonne of bubbles, but you’re usually stuck at your house where you’ve got power. A while back I had an idea of putting a bubble machine on my bike. I found a model that ran on batteries, and Tori did a bunch of thinking, and came up with an attachment mechanism. Now, as I ride my bike there is a trail of bubbles. When I stop my bike, there are bubbles everywhere, and when I walk my bike, if the wind is to my back, I’m engulfed in a wall of bubbles.

title: 581AZ - CHEF ZACH'S AMAZING WEEK OF COOKING.
excerpt: This week Zach took a stay at home cooking class. It was really neat, every morning they delivered the ingredients, and then every afternoon they turned Zach into a Chef. And then every evening they turned our kitchen table into a gourmet restaurant.

title: ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED - DOUBLE DATES!

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 584AZ- PORTLAND TRAIN DAY TRIP
excerpt: All summer Zach’s been fantasizing over a train adventure, and all my time in Seattle I’ve been fantasizing about going to Portland. On Friday when Zach suggested we could do a train trip to Portland, I was like, OK lets do it. Sunday day Trip!

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 585AZ- LAST CAMPING TRIP OF THE 2021
excerpt: Tori booked our final tent camping trip of the year in April for mid-September, and I was super skeptical. Way too cold I thought, no way we’re tenting that late in the season. Great news, as often the case, I was way wrong. We had a wonderful camping trip at deception pass!

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 587AZ - AMELIA NOODLES WITH AMELIA ON THE SIDE
excerpt: Long ago, Amelia was in a dark mood, so I said well, in that case, we should get “Amelia Noodles”. Her mood instantly brightened, and he had a fine date eating Pad Thai. Yesterday, it was our weekly date night and we decided on Amelia noodles. Subway, desert, future jobs and shotguns for boys, it was amazing! ps: best parenting tip ever - weekly date nights. pss: best story about this in 7 habits chapter 3.

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 588AZ - SUPER PRIDE! ZACH LEARNS GITHUB
excerpt: Friday I woke up at 4:30, and Zach, my 11 year old son, was awake. Slightly groggy, in disbelief, I say “Zach - what is going on? Go to bed! you have school in 4 hours. Go to bed!”. He reported proudly, “can’t I already had my Yorkshire gold tea (for some reason this is caffination of choice, think red bull or mountain dew for most programmers)”.

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 589AZ - HAPPY HALLOWEEN 2021
excerpt: Oh no it’s normal. See, I’m little red riding hood and I was adopted by a family of penguins. That’s what Amelia said to anyone asking why she was tricker treating with Zach a Penguin, and her there were penguins hovering on the side walk!

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 590AZ - KIDS ARE VAX'D!!!
excerpt: On November 8th 2021, 16 months after the CV-19 shutdown, the kids got their first vaccine shot! We got the shot at the hospital by our house which is right beside the subway station, so to celebrate we hopped on the subway and went to Zach’s favorite restaurant - Tai Tongue. To quote Zach, it’s delicious, easy to get to, and reasonably priced. A winning combination. Oh yeah, and that’s me taking a selfie with one of the photos in the hospital while the family groaned that I needed to get going.

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 591AZ - TURKEY DAY 2021
excerpt: Programmer Chef Zach shined this thanksgiving, cooking our thanksgiving dinner (with the help of souse chef Tori), and starting a programming course (after patiently explaining to Dad that Dad didn’t know how to teach programming). Curious, compassionate, resilient Amelia, enjoyed a sleep over, lots of Tara time, and shared dating guidance with Dad. Dad went crazy on his blog, and got to get the kids back at the roller rink. With a respite from Corona Virus we caught up with the Migas. And most important, to Tori, was are all grateful, who while preferring to be in the background makes all the magic happen.

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 601AZ - DIM SUM AND GROCERY STORE TREATS
excerpt: A quiet few weeks. Yesterday we went out to get some Dim sum, and went to an Asian grocery store. Doesn’t sound like much, but it’s been Covid for a while, and now that the kids are vaccinated and the parents have had the booster, we feel lots safer.

title: ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED - ZONG!
excerpt: Zong! It’s like Pong, but Zach made it! For the past few weeks Zach has been taking an interactive programming course. Today, on Christmas Eve 2021, Zach finished the first major project - writing Zong (aka Pong bit the ball has a big Z on it :) ) ! I’m so proud of Zach, not only did he write the game, but he’s been doing 2-4 hours a week of programming, and much of it with me. It’s a pleasure to be a part of this.

title: ICE, ICE BABY - JUMP IN THE LAKE DAY 2022
excerpt: It’s Jump in the Lake Day - that day we kick off the year by saying F@#$ the resistance!! This year the resistance was extra strong. It was whispering are you crazy, it’s sub zero and snowy, and there’s COVID so it’ll be solo. Luckily for me, water is warmer then air, my family supports me when I plunge, and my bestie Ammon reminded me how important it is I do this!

title: WEEK 604AZ - SWIMMING, ZEMORY AND AMAZING HABITS, PRODUCTIVITY
excerpt: This week we go back to work, school, and the gym. For our date night Amelia and I got back in the pool, Zach finishing his latest programming game Zemory, I took the kids out for lunch, and Zach and Amelia did their first walk home from school.

title: WEEK 605AZ - CALIBRATIONS, CALIBRATIONS, CALIBRATIONS.
excerpt: As a manager, the most intense thing I do is prepare for calibrations, that’s when we represent the work the teams’ we support have done, and ensure everyone is reviewed fairly. Even though I’ve done calibrations at 3 companies which have north of 1 trillion market cap for over a decade, I still take it incredibly seriously, and allocate a tonne of energy to it, and get flashes of stress doing it.

title: WEEK 606AZ - THE REVIEW PUSH PART 2.
excerpt: Last week I talked about how hard reviews are, and this week was an even longer, and even more emotionally draining week. Thursday I worked 14 hours from 5am to 7pm. As Tori says - “all plays open, and all plays close”. Even though there is one more week till reviews are wrapped up, most of the work is done, all that’s left is dotting the i’s and crossing the t’s. To toot my own horn, this year I had to write lots of reviews, and I did it a fantastic job. I had to write much more then I usually do, and I did it well with almost no procrastinating.

title: WEEK 607AZ - REVIEWS COMPLETE
excerpt: This Friday ended the 3 weeks of reviews (and here), and I did to the best of my ability and with almost no procrastinating, pretty proud of myself. As they say, if you want something done give it to a busy man., On top of work, my habits have been strong, I restarted practicing magic, I’ve been nailing it at the gym, and having a blast at my new habit - taking silly selfies.

title: WEEK 608AZ - CHILLING'
excerpt: This week I restarted my “day job”, and took a much needed easy week. Tori’s been super busy at work as she’s in Tech for her play, so I’m picking up some kid duties to pitch in - driving the kids to school and a few days of cooking. It’s very weird car commuting, I haven’t done that since at least Zach was born, and probably longer before that. My cooking repertoire is a little light, but fun to be making stir fry’s and my new wok is in the mail!

title: WEEK 609AZ - PLAY OPEN - THE MYSTERY OF IRMA VEP
excerpt: Friday we went to see Tori’s show. It was amazing, awesome props, super funny, the kids and I loved it. I fantasize about Tori working for the circus, and Irma Veep was pretty darn close. Once plays open the Prop folks (Tori was the Prop Master) get a much needed break after the grueling hours of Tech.

title: WEEK 610AZ - PANDEMIC ENDING, LIFE GETTING BACK TO NORMAL.
excerpt: The future is bright. The Governor announced the end of the mask mandate (1 more month), and last Saturday, after finishing my work out, I missed a turn and drove past my old favorite coffee shop by accident. It was my old favorite because it had closed during the pandemic. To my excitement it was open!!! I spent the next 3 hours enjoying my coffee, practicing magic, and writing on my iPad. Very much one of my favorite things to do. I was also really busy at work so I could take the next week off as the kids were off school. Amazingly I got it all done by mid week (though I did have to work a bit on the weekend), and can go into my time off with a very clear head.

title: WEEK 611AZ - DOWNTIME
excerpt: I took the week so I could spend the week off with Tori and the kids who also had the week off. Given it was a staycation, I had low expectations, and that’s basically what happened. Just a 7 day long uneventful slow weekend. It happens, next time I should plan something. In good news, I got a bunch of fun stuff done on my blog, and I started practicing magic hard again. Too hard, of course, as now my wrist is killing me, but luckily I have lots of PT exercises to make that better, and nothing motivates me to do those exercises like some acute wrist pain.

title: WEEK 613AZ - MARCH 12TH, 2022 - MASKS COMPLETE

title: WEEK 614AZ - BACK TO THE NORMALS ...

So far the ladies haven’t got COVID, but it’s still early. It was extra bad timing for COVID since it was spring break, and Tori was super busy working on her play. title: WEEK 656 AZ - LAYOFFS AND NYC W/AMMON
excerpt: This has been a crazy two weeks. First of all, on Wednesday Meta had its first layoffs ever, and I had my first experience going through layoffs and a giant re-organization where I’d be working on completely new things with a completely new boss. Not very fun. Making it worse, I’d planned a trip to NYC months ago with Ammon, and I flew to NYC Friday, just 2 days after layoffs while the team was trying to digest layoffs, and trying to understand what would happen next. As a result even though I was in NYC, I was trying to work a few days a week to help support the team through this difficult time (for them and me).

title: WEEK 657 AZ - ASHLAND 2022!
excerpt: You know what’s great? Going off the grid, where power is generated from the sun, water is collected on the roof, and there is 1 gigabit internet. This week we did our annual pilgrimage to Ashland for Thanksgiving. We saw Maureen, Brian, and the rest of Tori’s extended family. Zach got exposure to lots of dogs, I made lots of balloons, and Amelia followed in the family tradition of driving the bob cat.

title: WEEK 658 AZ - BALLOONING AND ZACH THE GREAT
excerpt: It’s been a good week - participating in Zach’s journey to a healthier lifestyle, connecting with my daughter Amelia as we watched our first tv series together, and creating magical memories of joy and fun at Amelia’s school party as a balloon-maker! Who knew with a little bit of exercise, a great show, and some balloons, I could achieve such contentment! And this is my first blog being co-authored by AI!

title: JUMP IN THE LAKE DAY 2023 - CLASS ACT EDITION
excerpt: It’s Jump in the Lake Day - that day we kick off the year by saying F@#$ the resistance!! This year is all about being a class act, and this year that manifested by coming up with a Jump in the lake compromise. See, historically I plunged at a lake that was super crowded, meaning you’d have to get there early park really far away, and schlep to the beach. While I enjoyed this, the family was less enthusiastic since they were only there to support me. So this year, I decide to jump into a quiet lake where there was no parking and we could be done quickly!

title: WEEK 687AZ - MANIC MEATBALLS, AND OUR NEW CAR (TESLA!)!
excerpt: (Zach writes) It’s not every day that you get dragged along on a 60-minute road trip by your maniacally gleeful brother to get some fast-food meatballs. But when that day comes, and it will happen, I will be the maniacally gleeful brother. If I am being truthful, I have no idea why I set my sights on Manic Meatballs, the fast-food meatball restaurant in question, or what drove me to spend 60 minutes in a brand-new Tesla Model Y to get there. Maybe it was a sense of childlike wonder. Perhaps it was divine providence, a call from the gods that meatballs were to be had. Whatever the case, I did it.

title: WEEK 700AZ - FATHER BURRIES GRAND FATHER; SON BURRIES FATHER

Painful for the loss, but Aaron was lucky to die peacefully at the age of 80 having had a joyous life and getting to have grandchildren.

title: ACHIEVEMENT UNLOCKED- YELLOW DELI
excerpt: “I ask you a question. When your answer makes no sense, I ask you more questions”. It was a dark and stormy night, and the Canadian border agent was not happy with my answer. 2 minutes earlier Border Guard: “Why are you coming to Canada?” Igor: “To go to the yellow Deli!” Guard: “What, you drove 3 hours for a sandwich?” Igor: “6 hours we’re coming back tonight. But. Yes, it’s run by a Jewish cult!”. … After many questions concerning gun ownership, switchblades, and unsavory characters the guard let us pass. On the way back, having experienced the yellow deli, I was filled with conviction on how great the experience was, and gave the guard the directions to get there.

title: FAMILY JOURNAL 718AZ - ZACH'S TAKE ON THE YELLOW DELI
excerpt: Over the border, there is a place unlike any other. Nestled between urban Vancouver and the rural wastes beyond, there lies a small, unassuming restaurant. This homely establishment is known simply as “The Yellow Deli”. Beyond the Deli’s quaint and rustic veneer, you will find a religious organization many repute as a cult. Formally known as “The Twelve Tribes of Israel”, they have been known to use tactics commonly associated with cults to both gain and retain followers. Becoming a truly devout follower of The Twelve Tribes is no walk in the park, however, as the majority of virtuous members seemingly live in hippy-esque communes that grow their own food and share everything. Interestingly enough, it seems that, politically, at least, The Twelve Tribes are your run-of-the-mill libertarians. Throughout the The Twelve Tribes’ history, there have been many child abuse allegations levied against them. According to the Tribes, children are but tiny adults and are therefore assigned the same responsibilities of their older peers. Adding to the allegations of “cultiness”, many former followers have denounced The Twelve Tribes after they left the communes.
